Calculus.name: Properties of Real Numbers
Calculus.formula: \forall a, b, c \in \mathbb{R}: \quad a + b = b + a, \quad ab = ba, \quad (a + b) + c = a + (b + c), \quad a(b + c) = ab + ac
Calculus.description: The real number system satisfies commutative, associative, and distributive laws.

example.problem: \text{Verify the distributive law for } a = 2, b = 3, c = 4.

Calculus.name: Triangle Inequality
Calculus.formula: |a + b| \leq |a| + |b|
Calculus.description: The absolute value of a sum is less than or equal to the sum of absolute values.

Calculus.name: Absolute Value Function
Calculus.formula: |x| = \begin{cases} x & \text{if } x \geq 0 \\ -x & \text{if } x < 0 \end{cases}
Calculus.description: The absolute value represents the distance from zero on the real number line.

Calculus.name: Absolute Value Inequality
Calculus.formula: |x| < a \iff -a < x < a, \quad |x| > a \iff x < -a \text{ or } x > a
Calculus.description: Inequalities involving absolute values describe intervals on the real line.

Calculus.name: Interval Notation
Calculus.formula: \text{Open interval: } (a, b) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : a < x < b \} \\ \text{Closed interval: } [a, b] = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : a \leq x \leq b \}
Calculus.description: Intervals describe subsets of the real line, with open intervals excluding endpoints and closed intervals including them.

Calculus.name: Delta Neighborhood
Calculus.formula: N_{\delta}(a) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : |x - a| < \delta \}, \quad \delta > 0
Calculus.description: A δ-neighborhood is the set of points within distance δ of a.

Calculus.name: Deleted Neighborhood
Calculus.formula: N_{\delta}(a) \setminus \{a\} = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : 0 < |x - a| < \delta \}
Calculus.description: A deleted neighborhood excludes the center point, including only points within δ distance but not a itself.

Calculus.name: Open Set
Calculus.formula: S \subseteq \mathbb{R} \text{ is open if } \forall x \in S, \exists \delta > 0 : N_{\delta}(x) \subseteq S
Calculus.description: An open set contains no boundary points, meaning every point has a neighborhood fully contained in the set.

Calculus.name: Closed Set
Calculus.formula: S \subseteq \mathbb{R} \text{ is closed if it contains all its limit points.}
Calculus.description: Closed sets contain their boundaries, including all points where sequences in the set converge.

Calculus.name: Limit of a Function
Calculus.formula: \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = L \iff \forall \varepsilon > 0, \exists \delta > 0 : 0 < |x - a| < \delta \implies |f(x) - L| < \varepsilon
Calculus.description: The epsilon-delta definition of a limit describes how function values approach L as x approaches a.

example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{Let } f(x) = 3x + 1, \text{ evaluate at } x = 2: \\
f(2) &= 3 \cdot 2 + 1 = 7 \\
\text{To verify with } \varepsilon-\delta: \text{ Choose } \delta = \frac{\varepsilon}{3} \\
|f(x) - 7| = |3x + 1 - 7| = |3x - 6| = 3|x - 2| < 3\delta = \varepsilon \text{ when } |x - 2| < \delta \\
\text{Thus, } \lim_{x \to 2} (3x + 1) = 7
\end{aligned}

Calculus.name: Limit at Infinity
Calculus.formula: \lim_{x \to \infty} f(x) = L \iff \forall \varepsilon > 0, \exists M > 0 : x > M \implies |f(x) - L| < \varepsilon
Calculus.description: Defines function behavior as x grows arbitrarily large.

Calculus.name: Cluster Point
Calculus.formula: x_0 \text{ is a cluster point of } S \text{ if } \forall \delta > 0, (N_{\delta}(x_0) \cap S) \setminus \{x_0\} \neq \emptyset
Calculus.description: Cluster points are limit points of a set, where every neighborhood contains other points of the set.

Calculus.name: Isolated Point
Calculus.formula: x_0 \in S \text{ is isolated if } \exists \delta > 0 : N_{\delta}(x_0) \cap S = \{x_0\}
Calculus.description: An isolated point has no other points of the set in some neighborhood around it.

Calculus.name: Bounded Set
Calculus.formula: S \subseteq \mathbb{R} \text{ is bounded if } \exists M > 0 : |x| < M \ \forall x \in S
Calculus.description: A set is bounded if it lies within some finite interval.

Calculus.name: Bolzano-Weierstrass Theorem
Calculus.formula: \text{Every bounded infinite subset of } \mathbb{R} \text{ has a cluster point.}

variables.S: Bounded infinite subset of real numbers

Calculus.description: Key theorem in real analysis about accumulation points of bounded infinite sets.

Calculus.name: Function Definition
Calculus.formula: f : A \to B, \quad f(x) = y
Calculus.description: A function maps each input from the domain to exactly one output in the codomain.

Calculus.name: Even and Odd Functions
Calculus.formula: \text{Even: } f(-x) = f(x), \quad \text{Odd: } f(-x) = -f(x)
Calculus.description: Even functions are symmetric about the y-axis, odd functions are symmetric about the origin.

Calculus.name: Periodic Function
Calculus.formula: f(x + T) = f(x), \quad \forall x
Calculus.description: A function repeats its values after fixed intervals called the period.

Calculus.name: Monotonicity
Calculus.formula: \text{Increasing: } x_1 < x_2 \implies f(x_1) \leq f(x_2), \quad \text{Decreasing: } x_1 < x_2 \implies f(x_1) \geq f(x_2)
Calculus.description: Monotonic functions either preserve or reverse the order of inputs.

Calculus.name: Local Extrema
Calculus.formula: f(x_0) \text{ is a local max if } \exists \delta > 0 : f(x_0) \geq f(x), \ \forall x \in N_{\delta}(x_0)
Calculus.description: Local maxima and minima are points where the function achieves higher or lower values in a neighborhood.

Calculus.name: Continuity
Calculus.formula: f \text{ is continuous at } a \iff \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = f(a)
Calculus.description: A function is continuous if its limit at a point equals its value at that point.

Calculus.name: Differentiation from First Principles
Calculus.formula: f'(x) = \lim_{h \to 0} \frac{f(x + h) - f(x)}{h}
Calculus.description: The derivative is defined as the limit of the difference quotient.

example.problem: \text{Find the derivative of } x^2 \text{ from first principles.}

Calculus.name: Power Rule
Calculus.formula: \frac{d}{dx} (x^n) = n x^{n-1}
Calculus.description: The power rule provides a formula for differentiating power functions.

Calculus.name: Trigonometric Derivatives
Calculus.formula: \frac{d}{dx} (\sin x) = \cos x, \quad \frac{d}{dx} (\cos x) = -\sin x, \quad \frac{d}{dx} (\tan x) = \sec^2 x
Calculus.description: Standard derivatives of basic trigonometric functions.

Calculus.name: Inverse Trigonometric Derivatives
Calculus.formula: \frac{d}{dx} (\sin^{-1} x) = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \quad \frac{d}{dx} (\cos^{-1} x) = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \quad \frac{d}{dx} (\tan^{-1} x) = \frac{1}{1 + x^2}
Calculus.description: Derivatives of inverse trigonometric functions.

Calculus.name: Hyperbolic Derivatives
Calculus.formula: \frac{d}{dx} (\sinh x) = \cosh x, \quad \frac{d}{dx} (\cosh x) = \sinh x, \quad \frac{d}{dx} (\tanh x) = \text{sech}^2 x
Calculus.description: Derivatives of hyperbolic functions, analogous to trigonometric derivatives.

Calculus.name: Product Rule
Calculus.formula: \frac{d}{dx} [f(x) g(x)] = f'(x) g(x) + f(x) g'(x)
Calculus.description: The product rule gives the derivative of a product of two functions.

example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{Let } f(x) = x^2, \ g(x) = e^x \\
f'(x) = 2x, \ g'(x) = e^x \\
\frac{d}{dx} (x^2 e^x) &= f'(x) g(x) + f(x) g'(x) \\
&= (2x) e^x + x^2 e^x \\
&= e^x (2x + x^2)
\end{aligned}

Calculus.name: Quotient Rule
Calculus.formula: \frac{d}{dx} \left( \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} \right) = \frac{f'(x) g(x) - f(x) g'(x)}{[g(x)]^2}
Calculus.description: The quotient rule gives the derivative of a quotient of two functions.

Calculus.name: Chain Rule
Calculus.formula: \frac{d}{dx} [f(g(x))] = f'(g(x)) g'(x)
Calculus.description: The chain rule gives the derivative of a composite function.

example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{Let } u = g(x) = x^2, \ f(u) = \sin u \\
f'(u) = \cos u, \ g'(x) = 2x \\
\frac{d}{dx} [f(g(x))] &= f'(g(x)) g'(x) \\
&= \cos(x^2) \cdot 2x \\
&= 2x \cos(x^2)
\end{aligned}

Calculus.name: Implicit Differentiation
Calculus.formula: \text{For } F(x, y) = 0, \quad \frac{dy}{dx} = -\frac{\partial F / \partial x}{\partial F / \partial y}
Calculus.description: Implicit differentiation finds the derivative of y with respect to x when defined implicitly.

Calculus.name: Higher Order Derivatives
Calculus.formula: f^{(n)}(x) = \frac{d^n}{dx^n} f(x)
Calculus.description: The nth derivative of a function, obtained by differentiating n times.

Calculus.name: Leibniz Rule for nth Derivative
Calculus.description: General rule for the nth derivative of a product of functions.

example.problem: \text{Compute the second derivative of } x^2 e^x.

Calculus.name: L'Hospital's Rule
Calculus.formula: \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f(x)}{g(x)} = \lim_{x \to a} \frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)}, \quad \text{if } \lim_{x \to a} f(x) = 0, \ \lim_{x \to a} g(x) = 0 \text{ or } \pm\infty
Calculus.description: Used to evaluate indeterminate forms like 0/0 or ∞/∞.

example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
f(x) = \sin x, \ g(x) = x \\
\lim_{x \to 0} f(x) = \sin 0 = 0, \ \lim_{x \to 0} g(x) = 0 \text{ (0/0 form)} \\
f'(x) = \cos x, \ g'(x) = 1 \\
\lim_{x \to 0} \frac{f'(x)}{g'(x)} = \frac{\cos x}{1} = \cos 0 = 1 \\
\text{Thus, } \lim_{x \to 0} \frac{\sin x}{x} = 1
\end{aligned}

Calculus.name: Indefinite Integral
Calculus.formula: \int f(x) \, dx = F(x) + C, \quad F'(x) = f(x)
Calculus.description: The indefinite integral is the antiderivative of a function.

Calculus.name: Definite Integral
Calculus.formula: \int_a^b f(x) \, dx = F(b) - F(a), \quad F'(x) = f(x)
Calculus.description: The definite integral represents the signed area under the curve between a and b.

Calculus.name: Integration by Parts
Calculus.formula: \int u \, dv = uv - \int v \, du
Calculus.description: Integration by parts transforms a product integral into a simpler form.

example.solution:
\begin{aligned}
\text{Choose } u = x, \ dv = e^x \, dx \\
\text{Then } du = dx, \ v = \int e^x \, dx = e^x \\
\int x e^x \, dx &= x e^x - \int e^x \, dx \\
&= x e^x - e^x + C \\
&= e^x (x - 1) + C
\end{aligned}

Calculus.name: Integration by Substitution
Calculus.formula: \int f(g(x)) g'(x) \, dx = \int f(u) \, du, \quad u = g(x)
Calculus.description: Substitution simplifies integrals by changing variables.

Calculus.name: Trigonometric Integrals
Calculus.formula: \int \sin x \, dx = -\cos x + C, \quad \int \cos x \, dx = \sin x + C, \quad \int \sec^2 x \, dx = \tan x + C
Calculus.description: Standard integrals of basic trigonometric functions.

Calculus.name: Exponential and Log Integrals
Calculus.formula: \int e^x \, dx = e^x + C, \quad \int \frac{1}{x} \, dx = \ln |x| + C
Calculus.description: Basic integrals involving exponential and logarithmic functions.
